channel.title: Dual Boot
channel.description: I'd like to dual boot win7 and ubuntu, where you can chose at startup which os to use. I read up about it, and it appears that I would have to put ubuntu (win7 is installed) on another partition. So I don't get how I would make it to get me to chose at startup since it will just run win7 since that's on the boot disk Any one experience with this, some tips; things I have to watch out for?

item.title: Dual Boot
item.dc:creator: @RandQm RandQm
item.description:
@RandQm wrote:

The Web Guy:

There’s not much you need to watch out for, it’s pretty straight-forward. You can get a free copy of Ubuntu from their site and burn it to a CD. You’ll need to create a partition which can be done through Acronis Disk Manager, Ubuntu shouldn’t need more than 25gb of HD space. Especially if Windows 7 is your primary OS that you use, you can also create partitions through windows administrative tools (disk manager). Next just put the Ubuntu CD you just burned into the CD drive and restart your computer, you’ll need to change the BIOS to boot from CD. The rest is straight-forward, it’ll boot to the on screen instructions to install Ubuntu, however, make sure you choose to install Ubuntu to the right partition of the hard drive.

I know what to do,
I was just confused on how it would give me the choice which os to run since it wouldn’t be installed on the boot partition.

item.title: Dual Boot
item.dc:creator: @Daginith Daginith
item.description:
@Daginith wrote:

[quote=“Niall, post:5, topic:466515”][quote author=RandQm link=topic=582166.msg4152296#msg4152296 date=1352501181]

Add another partition. (Shrink your current disk).
Burn the Ubuntu .iso to a disk.
boot the computer, loading the disk.
install Ubuntu onto the new partition.
Done!

Ubuntu comes with a bootloader that installs automatically.
This makes it so you can choose an OS.

So even if another partition is selected as startup disk, it will still give me the option?
[/quote]

assuming ubuntu now uses grub2, when you install ubuntu grub will automatically find your windows bootloader and chainload to that[/quote]Most major distros use grub2 now. Only ones like Arch don’t use it, and you have to manually add the windows partition to the boot loader, still not too tricky.
